>>52928426
I try not to use nana so unless a Pokémon is really pissing me off. Like you said, I’ll usually use them for feeding to my buddy or gym Pokémon, but if I really wanna make sure I complete a “ Make 5 curveball great throws in a row” or “Make 3 excellent throws in a row”, I use it on the last or second-to-last remaining skill throw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52928426
Nanab is maybe only for consecutive throw tasks. It's arguably useful for earning XP, whereas razz berry helps secure the Pokémon capture, and pinap berry expedites evolving and powering up Pokémon.

As you can reliably catch any Pokémon by being patient with your throws and learning how to best do curve balls, Nanabs are pretty useless and are better used as treats for your buddy or gym defenders. It also heals gym defenders more than regular razz or pinap berries.

Never trash berries by the way, put excess into gym defenders. You're allowed to feed 100 berries per 30 minutes, with 30 dust per berry for 3000 stardust, and an estimated 1/80 chance to get a candy from the defending Pokémon.

>>52945893
>why do people enjoy this again
They like the the rush of crushing even competent players with the ABB team style. I only do it for the stardust and elite charge TM for making teams that can solo Mega Pokémon.
>>meager stardust rewards along with useless mon encounters and evo stones
I usually go 1-5-1-5-1 in the lower elos so that I can get a good amount of stardust and 6 rare candy per day. Right now I'm at 1.1 million for this season alone, not counting the stardust gained from the battle pass or any of the December events either.

If Master League didn't usually give at least 5k stardust per set, and Battle Days didn't give at least 6k stardust per set plus a guaranteed elite charge TM, I wouldn't bother with any of it. The main thing you need to realize is that all the resourcecreep has been funneled into boosted stardust spawns like Delibird and the Meowth line, field research tasks like for Shellder, and GBL as a whole. Considering that certain bulky megas can require teams having a price tag of 3 million stardust just to have a mere chance of soloing them, you'll need all the power you can get.

Even if that sounds too intimidating for a normal player, everyone knows the power of Shadow Salamence and Shadow Dragonite, plus they've become especially important at their strongest now that we see how weak your average player is with the disastrous release of Mega Lati@s. Every point of power counts when you're surrounded by shitters.

Grass being immune to powder, dark to prio and the usual stuff give a much more powerful flavor to gamefreaks type; and really the greater sin of pokemon is how non-distinct some of its types already are.

For anyone who can help me who isn't familiar with how sprites need to be formatted to work for this.

>The front picture will need to be a png file with only four colors and a size of either 40x40, 48x48, or 56x56 pixels. The back picture is a 32x32 file, however the image itself is 28x28 pixels, with the bottom and rightmost four rows left blank. This is because the 28x28 image will be scaled up by 2 to fill the 56x56 space, but the dimensions of the file must be a multiple of 8.

This reminds me of a story: one time a horse got offended a porcupine said hello to him (it was an arrogant prick, so nobody should try to talk to him like a commoner).
He wanted vengeance, but needed help because the porcupine escaped, and he asked help to a human.
They team up, prepare a trap, the human mounts the horse, they kill the porcupine. Now here's the kicker: the horse said "thanks human, now you can leave", but he never left his mount.
Over time, the horse's species became enslaved by the human, and now he is forced to work FOR him, forever.

It's an tale that teaches you that if you are arrogant/weak, and you ask for help, be wary people tries to conquer you.

>>52923578
No plans to add more. I did this because I saw Gym Leader Matt's Gardevoir solo run & I couldn't get Sanqui to work for me. It kept randomizing gen 1 only as starter choices.

So I looked at the github page for pokered assembly for the 1st time ever, installed the required tools to get it work, & read the tutorials so I knew which .asm files to change. This was also my 1st time ever coding anything in assembly.

I grabbed the sprite from the video, resized it to fit, and had to find a plugin for paint.net that would simplify the existing sprite into only 4 colors. I converted it into a 4 color black and white. (Assembly instructions later add the green color if you are playing in full color mode.)

I used a gen 3 learnset for her limited to just the gen 1 attacks except she learns Growth when she would learn Calm Mind because Growth works the same as Calm Mind in gen 1.

She replaces Charmander in Oak's lab only. (He's still in the game.) but I could easily have her replace the other 2 instead. Starting with Ralts instead would also be possible if I just add the code for Ralts & Kirlia, but it wasn't what I was going for here.

I'm guessing she shows up as the first mon on the title screen because I had her replace Charmander. It was a complete accident but I was so happy when the game booted up and she was the first thing I saw on the title screen.

I spent about 6 hours doing all of this. The github tutorial was pretty straightforward, but I still had to trial & error some things.

I have no idea how to add a cry. Using asm it seems like cries are just a text file of numbers and each number has something to do with what pitch is played and for how long until the next pitch. It looks like standard audio files aren't used at all anywhere. Using one of the unused cries may be easier, but I'd like to figure out how to recreate her actual cry if I can.

Other than the cry, I have a fully functioning gen 1 Gardevoir. Not bad for 1/4 a day of work.

Tbh I don't think I do anything special, ever since I was a toddler it's grown really fast (even when I was born I already had my head fully covered lol). My mom also has really long hair so I'm guessing it's genetic. It's currently at 103cm more or less, last year it had a sudden growth spurt out of nowhere (was at like 96 before), don't know why. If it helps, I use Elvive shampoo and conditioner, though sometimes (like twice a month because it's expensive and I need it to last) for the latter I use Tio Nacho instead. I also don't brush very often actually so I'm not constantly pulling at it, and when I do it's very gentle (start from the bottom/tips, with your other hand grab just a bit above it so you don't pull, once that's done grab a bit higher and brush again, continue until you're brushing all of it).
It does become a bit bothersome at times, like getting it stuck in handles without me noticing and having my head pulled back, accidentally sitting on it, bending over and the tips touching the floor (awful if it's wet... ), but other than that it's really nice and I want to see how long it can get tbqh. I can wrap it like a scarf during winter, or feel like some forest fairy when I'm naked at home and it falls all over my body, idk it's just really nice and soft, I can also do a lot of hair dos which is fun.

>what are your thoughts on dudunsparce?
I approve wholeheartedly. Hell, I laughed my ass off when it was datamined and sent it to everyone I knew.

It retains the lovable dopiness of the original, continues the line as weird Japanese cryptids (Tsuchinoko to Nozuchi), stays true to the original gimmick (rare yet unremarkable) thanks to the variable segments, and pisses off the people who hopped on liking Dunsparce ironically because they wanted it to turn into something conventionally cool when it finally evolved. It's the evolution Dunsparce deserved, no matter what most people may think.

>>52918165
Imagine you're a 10-year-old. You're going on a week-long road trip to a family reunion where you aren't going to know anybody and because of a mixup you don't have any book or games for your gray brick Gameboy. All you have is the Gameboy itself, spare batteries, and the one game you happened to leave in it... which you saved up allowance for weeks to buy then realized you didn't like. There's literally nothing to do but play it. And play it. And play it.

This game is my personal hell.

Are there worse Pokemon games? Undoubtedly, but I've been lucky enough to avoid them.

https://www.siliconera.com/funny-stories-of-pokemon-english-name-localizations/
>Seth McMahill, Assistant Manager of Product Marketing at Nintendo, has been working exclusively on Pokémon games throughout his career at the company.
>When we spoke with McMahill recently, we asked if he had any interesting or amusing stories to tell from his days localizing the older games. McMahill recalled a couple of instances for us.
>“When you’re naming them, you’re together in a room with a counterpart from NCL (Nintendo Co. Ltd.),” McMahill shared. “We would basically have a thesaurus, a whiteboard on the wall, and would lock ourselves in for days on end, and the days would turn into months.”
>He continued: “The craziest one is… my wife was about to have a baby. So I’m at home, going through baby name books. I’m at work, going through baby name books, along with thesauruses and dictionaries. And after a while, stuff starts to sound weird. So, we had Piplup (Japanese name: Pochama), and the description from Japan was: ‘the sound of a small pebble in the water’. That was what we had to come up with.”
>McMahill recalls: “What we came up with was Piploop, which sounded like ‘poop’.”
>“And we didn’t even think of that,” he says. “No one thought of it. And we were talking to another group, saying we’d finally figured it out, and they went: ‘Poop?’ They said it sounded like poop. And I said, ‘It does not sound like poop! You don’t know what you’re talking about; I’ve been doing this for years!'”
>“And then, finally, after a good night’s rest, I thought: ‘That does sound like poop…’ So, we ended up with Piplup, which was the final name.”

>>52943814
> Can you use it to transfer Pokémon from older gens to Home?

Yes. Assuming you know nothing about it; bank was the precursor to Pokemon Home and was used to move from gen 5->6->7 and then up into Home when they changed to that system instead.
When the e-shop closes in March, you won't be able to download it onto a 3DS system anymore. They said they're making Bank free at that point though and no longer need a subscription so anyone that does have it can freely move all their pokemon into Home.

Presumably Bank will shut down at some point in the future, but they haven't said when.

Also, as much as I love Lysandre, his plan makes little sense when you consider that he wants a world of just "givers" and hired a legion of selfish socialites; the large entry fee may have worked in his head, but he had to have seen that it did not work in reality. Also, I cannot see a world as utopian as Pokemon ever reaching a point like Lysandre describes. I wish that he could have been in another franchise.

>>52943262
I used to think the same way as you, but I felt like I've better understood what Masuda is going for. Relating to the game from what Masuda says here, the angle that they were going for AZ and Lysandre makes more sense. I don't think it's purely a coiciendence that in Lysandre's final moments, you, your rival, and Shauna basically ask him to make a better world together, and when he doesn't accept, he literally dies. As a contrast, AZ who rejected the value of these things for violence wanders the world aimlessly, but once he makes the effort to try and better understand others (the parade scene which seems out of place), then he is ultimately rewarded with the life of his Floette. I think while the execution of some of its elements and themes can be juvenile or low quality, I think the core concept of what they were going for is incredibly strong from this perspective.

The villain teams that aren't "serious" suck because I don't care about beating them.
>Team Skull is just a bunch of goobers holed up in some town by themselves; there's no plan to be stopped and when they actually try to do something bad they're too incompetent to accomplish it
>Team Yell just want Marnie to win, but Marnie is indifferent to Team Yell, so I don't care about beating them because their "goal" clearly isn't evil
>Team Star are a group of sad losers that, aside from 2 bullies at the start of the game, do nothing bad aside from play hooky, so why do I give a shit about defeating them
"Serious" evil teams actually build towards a final confrontation and have growing anticipation about what that confrontation will be about. They allow for actual plot beats and story events, whereas the recent "evil" teams are just random mooks that are defeated with no consequences.

>>52938687
not him but here's what i usually think of when going for "not furrybait but still anthro"
>more monstrous pose- typically more hunched over or generally beastlier
>no fucking anime eyes, stick to either more realistic execution or go full weird and add no sclera
>deemphasize torso, keep proportions either understandably comparable to real life or somewhat equal and skinny. this especially helps since lankiness wards off the barafags to a minor extent
>tiny to no tail. ears where human ears go. emphasize monster aspect
granted this isn't typically applied to fakemon design since I don't do that stuff much, but tl;dr make it look less like a wolf on two legs and more like a monster hybrid with bad posture and clashing placement of features
something like what you posted is almost too "clean" for something like a werewolf, even some basic asymmetry could really help

>>52939941
Just to be honest, there was that episode from Master Quest called "Hocus Pokemon" in which the trio encounters a pokemon magician named Lily. While her spell flubbed and temporarily turned Ash into a Pikachu instead of its intended effect of letting him be able to understand pokemon, that was partly because the spell still had another page and she couldn't read it because it got smudged up. So if Lily could figure out how to restore that page or at least replicate the effect, she would be able to grant anyone the ability to understand a pokemon's mind. Which means magic, that is more based on a form of primitive science, is actually something that could be replicated by modern technology. And there was other formulas within that book that could be applied.

There is also that episode during Ash's training for the indigo league, "To Master The Onixpected" in which Bruno simply closed his eyes and put his hand on Onix in order to understand it, and then removes the Sandshrew that was causing the Onix pain. He even tells Ash that the hearts of humans and pokemon are connected.

There is also Oak simply telling Ash that pokemon that are caught take on the traits of their trainers during the episode "Showdown at the Po-Ke Corral". Which in Ash's case was referring to the fact that Charizard behaved like the worse aspects of Ash during his time in the indigo league.

There is more references to this sort of stuff that has been peppered throughout the series. Its just that a lot of the ones are stashed away in what people deem as "filler episodes" so they skip over that stuff as its not a gym battle or pokemon caught.

>>52941940
The definition has shifted over the years of what it means to be a pokemon master. The oldest interpretation is simply you are an elite trainer. Then it becomes catching all the pokemon, 151 at the time. Then it also is associated with completing the league and becoming a champion. Then it became you must have also beat Mewtwo. Then it became you must have caught a pokemon of each different typing. Then it became you, as a champion defending your title, can't be defeated. Basically the goal post always kept moving. Ash can still become one or has become one, it likely just means his journey will never truly end, and it will likely be something about perspective and how he just continues to do what hes already been doing, traveling and making friends and catching pokemon.

I think the main thing we will get with the 11 episodes is Ash bonding with people and pokemon alike as he catches some more pokemon. Whatever character moments we get between the humans and pokemon is basically what to look forward to.

Fucking THIS.
In Emerald in particular the gym leaders are way more daunting than they are in any other pokemon game. Details such as
>having 3-5 pokemon
>Ace always has a consumable item that aids them in some way
>All leaders have 2 healing items, usually saving one for the ace.
Really help bolster them to a level above the rest. Gym leaders in other gens just kinda... go down faster? Whereas pretty much all the hoenn leaders are genuinely built to be able to at least put up a fight even against their counters. Like the difference between Brock and Roxanne is really emblematic of how Hoenn gym leaders are built differently. You can always one shot both of Brock's mons if you have a grass or water mon, but against Roxanne even IF you're using any of the water or grass type mons you can get before her, you're not likely to be able to take out her nosepass in 1 or even 2 hits since it's pure rock, and has amazing special defense. That plus the berry and her 2 potions buy her enough Longevity that she actually get's to land some hits on you, making her at least not feel like a push over.

>>52929778
Some of these apply to RS but E is just a better version of those so..
>great region design, lots of places to explore, secrets to find.
>Unique atmosphere that elevates Pokemon's world into something much more it's own (this only lasted maybe one more gen)
>Overall great Pokemon selection, prioritizing new Pokemon which mostly have likeable, naturalistic creature designs.
>Lots of fantastic extra features to play around with while messing around in the game for hundreds of hours during car rides, etc. after beating the game (contests, secret bases, random rare daily events like berry master, mirage island, etc.) which combine with battle frontier to make the game feel infinitely long, something you could play forever.
There are some issues, the story has you go back and forth in the region in a fairly obtuse way later on, there's not enough variety of wild Pokemon on the surf routes to justify the encounter rate, and it was a game before the physical-special split which, once your old enough to think about stats at all, becomes very weird, with clearly physical moves used by physical pokemon being weak due to being a dark or dragon type move, though this is less a flaw with the game specifically and more an issue with the series up until the next game they'd release.
It's also a shame that a game that continued to move the series forward in terms of immersion and ability to mess around in the world long term didn't opt to include a day-night cycle, which was present in the previous games.

the whole point of convergents is to functionally have regional forms for environments a Pokemon couldn't survive in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52945576
Because it combines the best parts of the game (the actual game story and it's harshness) and the ashnime (AJ from the ashnime - the Sandslash Gym Leader guy- even makes a cameo) - it takes the ashnime tournament and explores what makes it cool in particular : awesome DP+XY ashnime season tier stratagems and stellar visual decisions.
Just read it.
The whole manga is focused on a tournament which is the best part of the ashnime since there are no "real" protagonists in that type of story, the one who wins doesn't win because he or she is the MC but rather the one who wins is the best trainer among others who are all on an equal footing which means plot armour is non existent, so the stakes REALLY rise since victory in a Pokemon battle in this kind of story is not predetermined by "protagonist-ness".
It's the ultimate formula for realism combined with idealism.
It really comes down to BOTH spontaneous battle tactics AND previous training, also a big deal of luck so the tension is always there. You literally can't predict who will win so that keeps you on the edge since the winner isn't the "good guy" and the loser isn't the good guy either actual.
It's not about being "a good person".
It's the clash of ambitions done in the spirit of the ashnime Gen1-6 Pokemon Leagues. Yes the ashnime SM and JN leagues were total trash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52945643
It just means that it got enough usage in OU to become OU. Smogon is a usage based tiering system so the more a Pokemon is used, the higher tier it is. Conversely, the less it's used, the lower tiered it is. Once every 3 months (or month early on), a Pokemon's usage stats are pulled and looked at, and depending on if it hits a certain usage threshold, it can either remain in a tier or drop to a lower one

Sometimes, Pokemon in lower tiers get enough usage in higher tiers to "rise", like Hatterene

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Self-Destruct and Explosion should have the same base power but Explosion should be a special fire-type move. They should both keep the defensive stat reducing stealth effect from before the nerf.

“Never miss” moves like Swift should still hit its target during moves like Fly and Dig like they did in Gen 1. It’s less about making sense and more about buffing underused moves for balance in a way that keeps the spirit of the move.

Tackle should have 35 base power with 95 accuracy like it originally had. It’s supposed to be a basic but mediocre move that weak Pokémon start out with. You’re supposed to be happy to get rid of it with something better. Buffing it to 50 is dumb and makes Nuzlocking Gen 5 a pain in the ass.

Bug should be super effective against poison-type like it was in Gen 1. Less about making sense and more about balance since bug-type is so fucking shit.
>make fairy-type
>give them resistance to bug just to make sure bug-type will always be shit
JUST

Moves like Sonic Boom and Dragon Rage should just do damage equal to the user’s move like Seismic Toss and Nightshade. Having a move only do 20 or 40 damage is really worthless outside of the first hour or two in the game. They’re also both equally worthless in competitive regardless of the generation, if that counts for anything.

Rock Smash should drop defense 100% of the time. The move is weak as shit and buffing it wouldn’t make any impact in competitive play. As it stands, the move is a shitty version of Power-Up Punch. And yeah, not everything should be balanced for competitive but shit like Constrict (10 base power?????) should at least work 100% of the time.
>Gen 1: lowers speed; 33% chance
>Gen 2-7: lowers speed; 10% chance
>Gen 8+: the move does not exist
LMAO. I get that some moves are meant to be weak to give them a niche but at least DON’T FUCKING NERF THEIR EFFECT WHEN THEY’RE ALREADY A WORTHLESS MOVE

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a few games now, GF has been buffing some of the lamer abilities. Like giving a lot of the crappy Gen 3 ones that just blocked Confusion/Attrraction or whatever the additional ability to block Intimidate, as an example. So what other ones would you tweak?

>Magma Armor
Becomes more like a defensive Water Bubble. Still blocks Freeze but also heavily reduces damage from Water and Ice moves (taking them to 0.25x damage, treating them as a double resist)
Why?: Only two lines get it and both are kind of garbage right now. This gives them an opportunity to mitigate a 4x weakness by cutting it by a quarter, making it a neutral hit, and then making Ice attacks deal 1/8 damage, as they naturally resist already. It doesn't radically change Magcargo into a good Pokémon, but it does have more chances to do something. Camerupt may benefit a lot more actually becoming more viable on different types of teams as a "Snow" counter or a good utility mon on Sun and Sand teams

>Corrosion
Still let's you poison Poison and Steel types, but now also works like Scrappy to let you ingore Steel's immunity to Poison moves altogether
Why?: It's kind of weird it doesn't work like this already. The Salazzle line doesn't really need this buff, but a special attacking Glimmora (rather than a suicide lead) becomes a lot more viable.

>Mycelium Might
Additionally lets your spore and powder moves hit Grass types
Why?: Another one that should probably just work like this anyway. Currently this ability is kind of garbage since it forces you to go last and the most frequent move you would be using, Spore, is already going to hit 90% of the things you're using it on. Might as well let it hit Grass types too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
Any ability that provides immunity to a status should now also provide bonus type 'resists', to match with purifying salt.
Magma armor reducing damage from Ice/Water movies is a good example. But you could also do a similar thing with Oblivious and Fairy moves, or Insomnia/Vital Spirit to shrug off psychic attacks. Immunity, Limber, and Water Veil helping against Poison, Electric, and Fire would also be a given.

I don't know if it'd make any mons with those abilities too crazy, since most of those with them have better options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
>Hyper Cutter
Prevents Attack lowering AND now buffs power of "claw" moves
Why?: Blocking Intimidate is kind of neat but all the Pokémon with this ability aren't very viable, which is a shame. Let's make it like Sharpness and recategorize a bunch of moves as "claw" moves. The actual description of this ability currently mentions you get the ability because you have a powerful pincer/claw. So some moves would have crossover with Sharpness, like X-Scissor, but there would also be uniquely claw moves like Crabhammer, Vice Grip and Crush Claw. Does this help a lot of Pokémon become more viable? Probably not. But I just really want to see Kingler and Mawile not be shit again.

>Big Pecks
Prevents Defense lowering AND now buffs the power of wind and wing moves (because you're using your big pectoral muscles to flap those wings of yours that make the wind, obv)
Why?: A lot of Pokémon have this ability circa Generation 5 and 6, then they pulled way the fuck back and I think only one new Pokémon has it since. It would be neat for the bird Pokémon who have this to actually get some benefit from it rather than just an immunity to defense dropping that doesn't really matter for them because they're not very defensive. Getting a buff to wind and wing moves would be nice. And the only reason I included wing moves is because they're so few why the fuck not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929372
I feel like those changes would only help competitive. There's a lot of abilities running around now that play with type effectiveness but not a lot of older Pokémon have access to them. That would be the fix and it generally would probably make them more surprising to play against

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The abilities that don't do anything in battle should all be given an actual purpose.

>Illuminate
Lowers the evasion of all Pokemon on the field by one stage. This goes hand in hand with the out-of-battle effect of making Pokemon easier to find by illuminating the area.
You now want to use Illuminate Starmie with Hydro Pump, Thunder and Blizzard.

>Run Away
The Pokemon can always switch out in trainer battles regardless of trapping abilities or moves. It baffles me how this is not already the case.

>Ball Fetch
The Pokemon can use Fling repeatedly without losing its item. This is a meme buff obviously but I still think it would be funny.

>Honey Gather
If the Pokemon is holding Honey, it will consume it at 25% health or less, restoring 50% of its max HP. At the end of every turn there is a 50% of the consumed Honey being replaced by a new one.

>Stall
Additional effect where this Pokemon holds off taking damage during the turn until it has finished attacking. This way it's not a complete dud. You're guaranteed to get something off before going down. The ability would activate when it gets hit and then the HP bar doesn't drop until after it moves. It could still take passive damage though, I guess

>Forewarn
Pokémon now still warns you about the strongest move of the adjacent opponent, instead of a random opponent in a double battle. The Pokemon is now then also guaranteed to avoid all damage the first turn right after switching in. This will help Pokémon like Jynx, Hypno and Musharna guarantee they can get off that boost or status move the first turn.

>Anticipation
The Pokémon still shudders if the opponent has a SE move or OHKO move, but now the ability activates every time either the user switches is in or an opponent does. Every time it shudders, it also gains a +1 Speed boost sorta like Rattled. Every one of the Pokémon that gets this ability has something else it would rather run, but it may have a niche use for some things. For example, DDing Whiscash can come in and guarantee it will be fast enough to get off the DD. Or something like Toxicroak, which has somewhat decent coverage, can be sort of a twisted revenge killer that doesn't have to rely on Sucker Punch to "out speed" a Psychic or Flying type.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
gonna give some solid buffs to some real stinkers

>Heavy Metal
On top of doubling weight, also halves damage from Fighting-type moves.
Why?: Pretty obviously, a thicker, heavier metal is a lot harder to break with your bare hands than something lighter.

>Light Metal
On top of halving weight, also halves damage from Ground-type moves.
Why?: This one's technically a bit of a stretch, as ironically weaker earthquakes typically affect smaller buildings more than larger buildings, while larger buildings are more likely to be damaged by severe earthquakes.
But "light" metal could also be interpreted as being a more flexible material, which would in fact be able to better absorb shockwaves than something more rigid.

>Keen Eye
Boosts accuracy upon entering battle.
Why?: Because it makes more sense for something with strong eyes to have a greater accuracy advantage than to simply be better at coping with sand getting flung into its eyes.

>Hyper Cutter, Big Pecks
Now also prevents the user from lowering their Attack/Defense respectively
Why?: They're already direct downgrades from something like Clear Body, might as well give it SOME kind of niche given that they're almost always paired with far better abilities anyways

>Anticipation
Raises speed if the foe has a super effective move.
Why?: Because Anticipation is garbage and learning whether your opponent has a coverage move against you is not worth sacrificing a real ability (which given its almost always paired with a far better ability, is usually the case)

I had a rant about this that I probably could really dig into and find. But I'll just paraphrase. I think that abilities were first created because they wanted to have a way to make Pokémon do things like levitate or change forms w weather but didn't know how to do it. From their abilities sort of evolved but they didn't want them to be anything overbearing, so we got stuff like hyper cutter. In comes generation 5 and they try to tweak the meta in a lot of ways, one of them was coming up with much better abilities. By 6 and 7 we now have a significant jump in abilities that are tailor-made for specific Pokémon and they wouldn't function without them. And then Generations 8 and 9 continue this trend, while also going back and tweaking older abilities.

>TLDR abilities were originally meant to be kind of useless, but their tune changed as time went on and now they pretty much define the Pokémon

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52939522
I don't disagree with having an open world Pokemon game, but I know its just how the series is going to be from now on instead of just a one off.
Basically every developer ever it feels makes the same mistake IMO, when the average person says "open world" I think they really are just talking about some freedom of exploration rather than "giant empty grassy fields". That being said you posted a BW route and while I like BW, I don't think routes were it's strong suit. I'd much rather see a largely expanded version of what Hoenn and Sinnoh were trying to do, but that will never happen even if GF isnt just going to do open world from now on because kid's get lost on any route that isnt just linear path + maybe random side path for one item.
I miss the more complex route layouts, I miss optional areas, I miss actual caves that arent just small tunnels between zones. SV do provide lots of optional areas but the problem is there's really nothing to do in them, the series has gone all in on "capture pokemon" as the main, core gameplay element, with the other elements that made the older games greater than the sum of their parts have been left at the wayside.
Now, this isn't to mention that for a developer that has so many issues on the technical side, routes with relatively restricted paths and the ability to block sight lines to hide LOD / pop-in would be hugely advantageous, but we saw them fumble that with SwSh too (desu, I feel like every route since they abandoned tiles feels very small, lifeless, and samey)

Regardless, gen 10 will be yet another open world, with another obligatory desert, snow area near the end, etc. instead of having a region with an actual climate identity.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52943436
SV sorta frontloads it's better level design, the opening area and the stone titan area are pretty good, but then you have a lot of fairly nothing fields and rivers north of that, until you get to the basically unfinished mountain.
Of course level design at that point is kinda screwed anyway because every open world game has made the unfortunate decision to have climbing and gliding be core mechanics, which while something that sounds good on paper, in practice I find it really takes something away from the world, you're no longer forced to engage with it, you just go as the crow flies to anywhere you want, plus this also helps to make visual fidelity overall worse since the game can no longer "cheat" by having areas of the map that don't actually have proper geometry and instead put that geometry into making the important areas more detailed. This was a problem both SV, PLA, and Monster Hunter Rise all shared for me.
SV also has a scale issue IMO, I think the fact that the world is designed to be ridden past on your bike legendary ends up meaning all the areas feel a bit too big / out of scale with just the regular player, and by extension extra empty. Honestly at this point I'd rather the series ditch the bike entirely and focus on making the level design more "human scale", which would just make it a lot more comfortable to hang around in. Using a bike felt like a sorta movement side-grade to me in the 2D games, and I would often spend more time running than biking, while in the switch games once I unlock fast transport I'm always using it, since the open level design basically means there's no downsides to doing so, and with the expectation that everyone is going to be using their bike / ridemon / etc, the level design also ends up a bit worse in a sorta feedback loop.

The world design kinda just ends up that way where you'll just sorta shuffle between those locations. While there are definitely well designed areas of the map, in my experience you only end up passing through them or visiting them for 10 minutes or so while you'll end up spending hundreds of hours in the empty areas mentioned previously.
Some areas are also underutilized, the Chinese area is interesting visually and satisfyingly dense, but by the time you go there you will surely have at least climb, which basically renders the whole area a non-area while also adding a lot of extra jank as you climb around the odd giant crystal things.
I also liked the sorta cave / tunnel thing between the mountain and the crater, but again, not really much to do there.
I do think every area is brought down by the mmo-like pokemon group spawns though, they somehow work to make things feel more artificial even if they're technically closer to reality than random encounters, and the low draw distance means you're spending more time staring at the ground than at the world. Honestly I think the game would be improved if pokemon spawns were 1/10th what they are but that's completely unrelated to the topic at hand.

Basically while there are some well designed areas, they're fairly small or make up a short part of the overall play experience, while the grasslands/farms/quarries/deserts take up the vast majority of both space and playtime, despite being largely filler.

You're acting like it's some sort of given that players will experience the "worse" option first, and that doing so inherently devalues the interesting geometry situated in those areas, and that isn't a mindset I can come close to agreeing with

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52945306
>Some areas are also underutilized, the Chinese area is interesting visually and satisfyingly dense, but by the time you go there you will surely have at least climb, which basically renders the whole area a non-area
I got there with climb unlocked and it didn't devalue the area in the slightest. I still got off and explored, and used climb to facilitate that exploration. I still spent a good amount of time on-foot because I felt like it and had the option to, which is kinda what this entire approach to game structure is about. Frankly, this reads like it's coming for the perspective of someone who either immediately defaulted to thinking that there wasn't anything worth exploring for, or just anted to get in, beat Eri, and then get out. In both of these cases, it's kinda on the player for not wanting to engage rather than the game's design somehow actively discouraging it.
>Basically while there are some well designed areas, they're fairly small or make up a short part of the overall play experience, while the grasslands/farms/quarries/deserts take up the vast majority of both space and playtime, despite being largely filler.
Just because they make up the "meat" of the region doesn't mean they'll inherently soak up most of the playtime. Like I described above, my playthrough was, in larger part, characterized by the more interesting locales the region had to offer with those grassy fields more so acting as a stopgap between interesting landmarks than anything else. I can't imagine I'm the only one who experienced it like this either given SV's region design is near universally considered "pretty good" to "amazing" (though I personally wouldn't go as far as to say it's the latter). I think here more than ever before the impression you come off the region with is dependent on how you ended up playing the game just by nature of the open world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52943616
I wouldn't exactly call a powerful Stab with the downside of needing to switch on a mon that loves to switch 'niche'.
I think the distinction in this case is that while predicting a Shed Tail and getting hit with a Knock Off, Rapid Spin, U-Turn, or Draco Meteor instead when you switch isn't too bad, predicting any of those others and them using Shed Tail means they've got a powerful set up sweeper who will get at least one turn for free.
And if you do predict the switch and send out a counter? They can hit your counter for some chip damage as you burn the sub, and then just switch out their setup sweeper for later. And Cyclizar is back to 83% thanks to Regenerator, meaning that as the game progresses, it can come back in, U-Turn or clear hazards, and attempt to do the same thing all over again.
And even if you take out Cyclizar, you still haven't actually dealt with the setup sweeper. You've simply made it harder for it to set up.

>>52943441
>I love how everyone can complain about how CrAzY the power level is then also bitch that a shitmon gets free weak subs
But it's not the shitmon getting a free weak sub. It's the next mon you send in getting the sub.
And a sub is a sub. Even if the sub only had 1 HP, it's still withstanding one hit for free. Nobody is claiming that Cyclizar is broken because it's making the other mon completely invincible. But it gives a free turn to the next mon sent in. Usually a setup sweeper.
You could say to use Taunt, but Cyclizar is fast.
You could say to use hazards, but setup sweepers are just as strong at low HP as they are at max HP.
You could say to use Dragapult, but taking a turn to switch in is still giving a free turn to the opponent.
You could say to use sound moves, but that means either switching on or using a full team of mons with sound moves.

Shed Tail just further enables the crazy power level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52943502
>So switch on the shed tail?
Anon, why do you think U-Turn and its variants have been such historically good moves?
It's because switching has the highest priority. Meaning that if you click a pivot move and your opponent switches, you can just go right into a counter to what they switched into in a single turn. This is known as "momentum".
The same applies to Shed Tail, but you also get a substitute in addition to the momentum.
Switching on the Shed Tail just means that your opponent can choose which Shed Tail recipient to go into to counter your counter.
>You can see what they are likely to pass to in preview
On a bad team, yes. A good team built around Shed Tail will have multiple recipients.
Bans are made with good players in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52939276
Depends on the selection of mons you're including. It could result in cases where fast and frail mons miss out on some key one-shots, and thus get knocked out more easily in return. It also makes bulky pokemon with reliable recovery more valuable, since they'll be taking less damage and healing it off more easily.

For an in-game playthrough though, the differences are more likely to be fairly minimal, so long as you aren't intentionally designing enemy teams around abusing the extra bulk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52939302
I would personally add them as companions/followers that don't take up a party slot. That way you can have their personality and appearance but not need to tinker with balance or figuring out how to make them something the player will want to use. Other anons made valid points that adapting the LGPE partner system isn't a terrible approach either, but I would recommend they are part of a pool you can select from / earn throughout the game.

I would personally implement them as a Pokemon that provides a noticeable buff to your team, similar to badge buffs. That way people who want to use their favorites have even more reason to do so, and others can use specific mons to craft a team that leverages that advantage. A lot of potential depth there with minimal investment, and you don't need to give up letting them be used in battle.

Sure they may be "easy" to find, but not at the prices the masses are willing to pay. I actually just watched the recent AI video and he summed it up perfectly. I'll paraphrase here but the gist of it was that once a certain threshold is reached, for clarity we'll assume that threshold is $300, there are only a select amount of groups that are able to / willing to afford it;
people that bought in or around $300. And when product dries up and tpci stops printing, the people that bought at $300 aren't going to want to sell for anything less than $300 and $300 will be the new floor. And prices will continue to rise from there. It happened to WOTC and I (and a lot of others) predict that it'll happen here too. Obviously not to the point of Base, but I mean if a chilling reign booster box you bought at $80 goes to $1k and you have 10 cases, well I would consider that a W, wouldn't you?

>reminder that serperior is a plant before it is a snake, that it photosynthesizes for nutrition instead of eating...
First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
Serperior's dex entries never state that it solely relies on photosynthesis. It would be pretty strange if it did, considering that it's been depicted eating stuff as I mentioned earlier.

The scarlet player is going to make his own sandwich. You and me will make one for ourselves.

Well we're splitting sandwiches.

I'm fine with any violet shiny, but I want valiant above anything.

I'm dedicating myself to hunting moon so it's dragon for me.


As for how to do it, you join the union circle, fly to gate and then either make your own sandwich or join one table.

After that, you go to the zone you want to hunt.
If you find a shiny, DON'T ENGAGE, warn us in this thread and save in front of it.

The player that finds a shiny gets it guaranteed as long as they save in front and DONT engage it, then one of the other players can come and get it.
After the sandwich ends, you can restart the game and as long as you didn't save again, you will be in front of the shiny.

The only Gen that straight up don't show the back end intent are 2, 4 and 5, even then you could argue 2 and 5 did a different sound and shine/bubble effect despite using the standard slash and 5 ended the animation with the largest part on the bottom rather than it starting with it as other slashing moves do, it's too ambiguous to convey it properly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52944442
Hi, Gameboy modder/repair here! Yes this will work, but I've witnessed 3 separate people attempt this and melt their Gameboys. Please for the love of God don't do this unless you have GOOD experience soldering. Retards have managed to break their carts and sometimes original consoles doing this. It's so much more convenient to use something like a GBxCart to just dump the save to your computer and return it to the cartridge after you safely replace the battery. Please do not be retarded.
If you still want to be a bastard and risk your Gameboy and cartridge, your best opportunity is on the original GBA and take off the back plastic shell of your GBA as well as the cartridge shell both front and back. You'll have to hook up the power with an external power source for the GBA; easiest cheap way is a simple 2 AA battery holder with alligator clip leads. You WILL melt one of the shells otherwise.

>How exactly do you get them into the games?
I use a software called PKhex and utilize my hack switch running custom firmware. Atmosphere for switch. I dump my game file into PKHex and edit it from there and then overwrite my current game file with the edited one.

Yeah I can help with that. I just need a pokemon you've bred or caught yourself to obtain the information.
>Can we already get the pokemon coming with Home or are they not in the game files yet?
They're in here but not tradeable. What I CAN do is have you bring a ditto and have it breed with the pokemon youre requesting in Union Circle and you can take the egg. We would have to make a sandwich with Egg Power buff.

You notice that ever since Gen 6 the third legendaries have gotten more bizarre and akin to cosmic horrors?
Zygarde's a cell-based hexagon Pokemon that has different forms and goes from dog to dragon to giant, and also the only one that's unconnected to it's region's gimmick somehow.
Necrozma's a prism dragon that harvests stars that happens to have split parts of it's body used as the region's gimmick.
Eternatus is a skeleton dragon that's a metaphor for nuclear energy.
Gen 9's third legendary, Disk-Kun, is some unseen beast lying beneath the Earth that's implied to either fuck with time itself or create things from imagination, as well as being behind Terastalization.
It's like they're trying to be Kirby bosses.

Giratina is not a Satan. It is not a Lucifer. It is not a Rival, Opposer, or Challenger. It's an untamed force of nature that tends to go on rampages but helps out Trainers when it feels like it.

Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. Or you could just decide that G/S/C is 100% noncanon and is fully replaced by the similar-but-slightly-different HG/SS content. Either way the idea of steel types being " recently discovered" doesn't work if you allow for the type chart to be something that exists within canon rather than a game extraction, because then the nature of reality somehow changes as pokemon researchers discover things. The setting turns into madness where subjective reality trumps scientific rigor and it gets worse then harder you try to make it make sense. Best to just ignore the retcon.

>>52941876
Well, one quick fix I'd make would be to highlight one aspect of her character that's mostly just hinted at in one or two lines, but isn't truly apparent till a side-story in the postgame: the sheer isolation that comes from her being 'the best'. Like sure, you know that she's obsessed with you because battling is her 'special interest' and you're really good at it, but it's not till the postgame that the game REALLY drives it in that she's just so damn good that nobody even wants to fight her anymore. And, if they do, she just steamrolls them and destroys their egos, which isolates her even further. Literally the only people who can match up to her are Gym Leaders, Elite Four members and Geeta herself, and they're all incredibly busy adults who obviously don't have a ton of free time.
So, in an attempt to improve some of the writing around her, I'd make it so there's a ton of mandatory dialog that highlights how tough she is, and how nobody wants to battle her anymore; maybe even some lines from Team Star, where they call you crazy for hanging out with that 'Student Council dweeb'. Imagine how much harder the cutscene in the final battle would've hit if you realized what the whole thing meant to her; that she's not just happy that you're a real challenge, but also because you're the only person in the whole region who 'gets' her; someone who just enjoys a good battle and will keep coming back, no matter how many times you win or lose. As long as you're still there, she won't feel like she's completely isolated from everyone except adults who're too busy with their jobs.
Oh and as >>52941912 said, I'd make her battles way harder than they are. EV training, IVs, beneficial natures, held items, the works. You can't sell a narrative about her being 'the strongest' if she's not actually...y'know, the strongest.
Of course, this is just one fix that I came up with off the top of my head. I'd also probably have her interact with Penny and Arven, but char limit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52940405
UUBL stands for UnderUsed Borderline.

All tiers in Smogon are primarily usage based, with actual strength being secondary. Borderline means that it was banned in the tier below for being too strong/centralizing/unhealthy for that meta, but does not get the usage stats to hit the tier above. So it's in the middle between UU and OU.

Using that tiering analogy, you could roughly think of UUBL as being Low Top Tier.

The problem with Tink is that even with Gigaton Hammer, it can't hold its own.
And I know it's meant to be a supportmon, but being a supportmon with such a weak offensive presence just leaves it with "all my friends are dead" syndrome.
Look at other premiere supportmons like Landorus-T and Incineroar and they both had slightly stronger STABs that they could spam every turn. Not even accounting for the fact that they could use other attacking moves, potentially.
>0 Atk Landorus-Therian Earthquake vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Mew: 150-177 (43.9 - 51.9%) -- 10.9% chance to 2HKO
>0 Atk Incineroar Flare Blitz vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Mew: 145-172 (42.5 - 50.4%) -- 1.2% chance to 2HKO
>0 Atk Mold Breaker Tinkaton Gigaton Hammer vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Mew: 135-160 (39.5 - 46.9%) -- guaranteed 3HKO
You could remove the downside from Gigaton Hammer and it wouldn't be broken. Tinkaton's low base attack is enough to balance it.

>>52943722
Context is important.
Corviknight is a pretty hated mon after the stallfest that was the gen 8 meta. I think almost everyone wanted it to be taken down a peg.
And then we get a Pokemon whose dex entries revolve around how much it BTFO's Corviknight. So people who got attached to the design wanted to flaunt how cool it was for beating up everyone's most hated bird.
But then in practice, Tinkaton can barely tickle Corviknight. It's disappointing. And Tinkfags who loved it for its design desperately try to cope rather than accept it for the shitmon it is.

You know how Zangoose's dex entries are all about its fierce rivalry with Seviper? Imagine if Seviper was a Ghost/Fighting type and was exactly 1 speed point faster than Zangoose. That's basically the situation Tinkaton is in.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>52911327
>What kind of cliffhanger does it end on?
It isn't a cliffhanger per se, but it's only the completion of the first story arc of an originally intended three, so there's a lot of stuff that's clearly setup for later resolution that's left open-ended. (It was supposed to be a graphic novel kind of thing but the original character designer and artist dipped about a dozen pages into the first chapter and the author was nine chapters deep, so finishing the first arc felt like the best compromise between not throwing all the work away and not committing to more than the extant work required.)

The problem/reason for that is that the author is a nerd and actually wrote about a dozen things and they're all set in the same continuity, so even ignoring the bits that were for the intended latter two parts, there's also a lot that references other stuff, including stuff that wasn't yet written when it came out.

All that aside, it's a couple dozen chapters of slice-of-life that takes an objective look at the gardevoir-waifu cliche, starter pokemon loyalty issues, where pokemon fit into a human family structure, the innately speculative fiction aspects of things like parallel worlds and transient land masses (as are canon in Pokemon but of a different sort here), the pressures of organized competition, latent psychic emanations, ghosts with attitude, adverse possession law, wildlife management, identity theft, and treatments for acute hypothermia.

But mostly people click on it because "Gardevoir" is in the tags.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>52910812
It may no longer be an issue but AO3 used to be notorious for a long sign-up queue. Apply well before you want to post there.

>zwcsp

>The closest was all the way in Sunnyville on the other side of the region. And that was a trip his parents weren’t willing to make.
Are you intending to imply that one must have a Professor-assigned starter to participate in League? Canon has people with pokemon from any origin; the Hero's Journey of Red, Ash, etc. justifies having a pokemon with viable BST.

I feel like this infodump should've been the entirety of Chapter 1 after the funeral scene cold open. As a bulky flashback, you could show rather than tell Travis's efforts to acquire a starter, and time-skip as needed to need only portray "the good stuff." Like, one scene of him trying to get a trip to Sunnyville, another where he's doing yard work to earn money to mail-order some pokeballs and then fails to catch anything with the one/few he gets, and so on. Another where he tries to borrow one and gets told plainly that his acquaintances won't entrust him with the care of their pokemon for several reasons giving him reason to introspect—that could be where he suspends the idea and it lingers and gnaws at him in the background till the expiration of Arcanine.

Instead we're spending a lot of time trying to sell the premise when either the reader is already willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of making acquisition of a starter a momentous (and hitherto belated) event in Travis's life, or it points out the contrivance and makes it more awkward.

The rest of the chapter works well enough, although maybe something more interesting could be done to get them together without it being "that simple." Travis could've lost his keys or phone and had to go back maybe, or leave the encounter a bust but later (after acquiring a starter) Travis goes up the mountain again to grind some levels and encounters it again, and then tries to add it to the roster.

>>52912683
> I really wanted to get things off the ground
The lack of immediate relevance of Travis's backstory prevents it from taking flight. A flashbacks sequence can _show_ the key events leading to Travis being here as he is and feeling the way that he does. Alternatively, the "fill that in later" path, would be to just play the funeral scene straight, have Travis choose to go for a walk instead of to return, and then use the walk as a way to establish. Maybe he sees some "first route" kinds of pokemon and laments that he couldn't even catch one of those when he did manage to get some balls. He could see someone with a quality starter and rue that his parents never agreed to a vacation trip that would include a stop at a Lab. And as he goes deeper into the wild and higher up the hill he could start to realize the danger he's put himself into and _then_ contemplate if even having a starter he might be as unprepared as he is right now. Stuff like that gives lots of opportunity for building tension while establishing backstory while the main story doesn't break stride.

>>52913832
I get what you mean with the pacing, I should really try to stop writing giant chunks of introspection like that. However one thing I can't compromise is the trip into the wilderness being incidental. It's very important that it was a conscious choice, since when I came up with the idea for the story, one of the main themes was to be complacency, and with that, a recurring thematic development of someone wanting to do a thing and then just doing it. I was explicitly trying to fit that kind of development twice into the first chapter just to establish it as strongly as possible, because I had planned to use it for future arcs and other characters, applying it in different ways and so on. That's part of why I was hesitant to open with a big flashback, because it doesn't let me establish the thematics I want quite as strongly out of the gate. I could go way heavier on the complacency, to be sure, but ultimately that would end up not hitting the tone I wanted for this first chapter

In any case, all that introspection is definitely due to get cut up and spaced out to make way for more actual things happening

"... And this is Master Florian. Everyone, please get along with him!"

After being introduced to my homeroom class, I quickly darted my eyes to find a place to sit. Nemona eagerly waved me over, sitting in the back corner of the room. Kind of weird, since I thought she'd be interesting in learning more about Pokemon considering her love of battling. I smiled at her and sat next to her in the back, looking forward with a rush of excitement as class began.

A few minutes in, I heard a weird noise. I looked over, seeing Nemona was making a clicking noise with a mechanical pencil to get my attention. When she saw me, she winked at me and moved her hand--my eyes traveled to follow it. She had unbuttoned one small part of her white school shirt and pulled it forward to show me the inside; I could see one of her boobs. She quickly refastened it and smirked at me.

>>52944106
that's the whole issue with fairy type, yaknow? it's not a part of the world, it's "the type made to nerf dragons". but what IS fairy type, exactly?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TN25ghkfgQA
fact is, every idea that fairy type could represent is already occupied by another type. does it represent nature? that's more of a grass thing. tricksters? dark type's domain*, to the point that there isn't a single dark-type attack without some secondary effect. some fairy moves are associated with the moon, but cosmic energy is firmly a psychic type thing. so is magic, for that matter. literal fairies? well, yeah, i guess, but there are a lot of fairy types that are not that. side note, the fact that I've just listed five different possible inspirations for the fairy type shows just how disjointed the type truly is.
many people hit a roadblock when trying to rebalance fairy type because they want to stay in line with the type's theming. but there is no theming to adhere to. fairy type...is nothing. the reason pokemon are fairy type is because they are fairies, and they are fairies because they are fairy type.

and if you still don't believe me, then ask yourself a few questions. why is Azumarill fairy type? why is Togepi fairy type? why is Ribombee fairy type? why are the Tapus fairy type? and why ISN'T Zoroark fairy type? and then compare your answers to all of these questions.

*I've heard a lot of people say that dark type is a more malicious form of deceit than fairy type, but I don't buy it. firstly because there are many "evil" fairy types that aren't dark type, and secondly because the fae of old are absolutely malicious and something to be feared.
